reviewText:
Do NOT buy this game if you plan to play single player.  It's miserable.

That said, I absolutely recommend this game for co-op with 3 or 4 players.  This game is a very tough gauntlet-style game, with puzzley elements frequently thrown in.  Yes, you are smacking monsters and trying to stay alive, while doing puzzles at the same time.  It's freaking hard.

But, it is very satisfying to complete the levels.

The only downside is that the netcode still isn't rock solid.  For whatever reason, I have a 20%ish game freeze rate when trying to start a group game, requiring me to totally shut down the game and restart.  Other than that, it seems ok.

reviewText:
Don't try this without friends, you'll go mad in singleplayer. Extremely difficult, we've spent over an hour on certain trials (still not done with all of them), especially difficult if you want to do the challenges. Controls work great on a controller, gameplay is overall interesting. The orb idea is a neat one, makes for fun and interesting puzzles, although you might kill your friends over it at certain times. You WILL have to go back and revisit previous levels to do the challenges, which provide the upgrade gems for abilities. I personally like this, challenges are usually fun and they really need teamwork, but I imagine it may bother some people playing the same levels over and over.

Plays best if you have friends over, you really need to communicate (yell, actually). The main reason why you really need friends for this. Everyone should have a mic and lots of patience, really difficult to have this with strangers.

Got a 4 pack in sale a while back, money well spent. We're at roughly 23 hours so far and still has a lot to offer, so I'm pretty sure you would be happy with it even at full price.

reviewText:
I really owe this game a review.  I've had more fun with this playing with friends than any other game.  No other game has permitted me to talk at such loud levels to the people sitting next to me.

It's a lot like gauntlent but a greater challenge in my opinion.  Where as gauntlent is more geared toward grinding mobs down, this is more for how well can you work together on a particular goal.  I haven't encountered many games that make you have to be this tightly coordinated.  Weak links will become apparent and quick.  Each level brings a new way of having to making a plan.  Each monster has to be learned how to be dealt with.  Kiting isn't an option.  Understanding how each fighter operates is vital.

My warnings:  This is meant for co-op.  You can play single player, but you aren't going to have as much fun.  More importantly, you will want to find a consistant person or so to play with, which I know isn't always easy.  Pugging this game usually ends in a bad result, and there aren't enough people in the lobby to make games happen when you have time to play.  Also, I would not say this is for a casual gamer.  If you haven't built up a reasonable degree of twitch, I feel you are just going to get frustrated.  I'm not saying people can't learn, but I've seen people that don't play a lot of games say this is not for them.

Games are fun, but to me this one was an experience.  One I could share with some good friends.

reviewText:
FORCED is a Action Role-Playing Game heavily pushing a co-op experience.

STORY
I would say the weakest part of the game, other than some of the technical issues that some people still experience (see technical) - would be the story. It's a very quick and short tale that leaves a lot to the imagination. I'm not saying it's bad; simply shallow. If  your goal is to find a rich story - you will not find it here.

ELEMENTS
All players have the option to play one of four classes which are determined in the entrance room to each trial room. It is also good to note that no matter the decision of the class; in most cases you will have healing spells, damage spells, and defensive spells of some kind. Other than the inherit differences between melee and ranged; the developers have done a good job at keeping most everything balanced. The true co-op experience comes into play before anyone even enters a trial; deciding who will have which spell to counter the trial mechanics. This is an element that most co-op games don't have.

GAMEPLAY
Once your skills and class has been chosen - per challenge - you will face 25 trials with increasing difficulty. As one may expect the game starts out in a tutorial manner, teaching players how to navigate the trial and use new mechanics. Balfus (your spirit guide) is an integral part of the gameplay, requiring players to move him to destroy shrines or statues, light the path, assist in damage dealing, or in some trials - used against you!The primary game play is to complete objectives which range from killing monsters, finding the end of a maze, or simply lighting shrines. As a side note I wouldn't say this is necessarily a game with heavy puzzle elements; however there is a degree of puzzle solving.

DIFFICULTY
If you plan on being a completionist, to get all 75 crystals and all achievements, expect to spend some time on this game. At the time of this writing I have completed all achievements in roughly 24 hours of gameplay. Most challenges took my team 1-10 tries; the challenge on the last boss took us roughly 4 hours. If you plan on simply completing the trials to have the experience to play - expect at best half of that. I would not recommend this game if you want to just play single player - this is a game best experienced with friends. Disclaimer: Your mileage my vary, every gamer and team is different you could see significantly less or more gameplay.

TECHNICAL
I have to peck at the game a bit on this level; there are still a few issues with networking that the developers are actively working on. In addition the game is poorly optimized in terms of graphics use. A lot of the options to effectively reduce load on a computers GPU is non-existant. My system with a GTX570 runs this game fine, but quite hot in comparison to other games with a much higher expectation (100% load in some areas running 70c+). I assume as the game matures further, the developers will continue solving some of the technical issues that some players are reporting as problems; they did not effect my team as much as some but it is important to note that they could come up.

CONCLUSION
Highly recommended for any CO-OP experience. This game is quite fun with a lot of potential for growth in the future. 9/10 for what it is, and for my experience.

reviewText:
A bit about the game and developers.
FORCED has been developed and published by a small group of Danish developers, called BetaDwarf Studio. They actually had a pretty funny story while making this game. In fact, it was so funny that they even made a picture about it which you can see here.

So, FORCED is a Co-Op adventure game with a lot of puzzle elements. The game does future single player, but I do not recommend that.. More about that in the Gameplay section of the review! They also plan to bring this game to Wii-U!

About Gameplay.
As I said above, Forced is a game that allows both single player and co-op. At begining I was playing this game single player. My steam friend list has a couple of people who own this game, but nobody played at the time when I did. So anyway, In single player the game is quite fun! The story is very good too. It wasn't so hard, and I really enjoyed it. But then, couple of missions later... It became quite hard! So, I got into the game once at the same time as my friend FaithNoMore did. We decided to try the game out in Co-op..

It was amazing! The game became much easier but it kept being harder and harder as we progressed through the challenges. In most of the cases one of us was always the last-man-standing, running around the enemies, doing his best to stay alive long enough for the other person to revive. We also found out that this game is actually meant to be played in four people! After a while, our obstacles became quite hard. So hard that one of us had to keep sacrificing just so we could complete a mission. If there were four of us, it would be piece of cake!

The game has four different classes, a rogue, archer, tank and a area of damage" damage dealer. Each of them has their own element. Rogue uses poison and has teleportation skills and skills that get him out of combat quite fast. He's the best class to take creatures down one by one. Archer uses lightning element with which he deals nice damage to couple of creatures at the same time. His arrows also always push enemies back
date: so he doesn't have too big problem with staying alive. Tank uses ice element to make ice crystal around him which then pushes enemies back
recommended: and so on and on. Needless to say he's got the biggest hp. He also has a weapon (shield) which can be thrown away to enemies. Now
hoursPlayed: the AoE damage dealer uses fire element to deal very big damage to multiple creatures at the same time. Sounds overpowered
voteText: right? Well
helpfulPercent: he does deal big damage
votesHelpful: but he swings very slowly. He can also crush a meteorite down onto the enemies.\n\nThis game also has a lot of different creatures that you have to fight against to win. All of them have their own strength and weaknesses. Some spit on you from far
votesTotal: some charge you with their massive cleaves. And once again
votesFunny:
you need a full group of four to make a great tactic on how to win against the creatures.

Graphic and Audio
Graphically speaking the game looks very good! The game itself looks a bit cartoonish. The skill effects look quite nice. For an Indie company they really put their backs into it! Voice acting in the game is very good too!

Pros

cons and final grade.

reviewText:
If you are looking for a couch coop game, this one is the best or one of the best.
Levels include increasingly challenging puzzle and hack n slash level. Some levels are almost purely slow puzzly levels, some are fast paced fighting levels and rest are some combination of those two.
Game mechanics are simple and are introduced sufficiently smoothly so you don't feel overwhelmed. Later on these mechanics are combined in various ways and the game never feels boring.

Biggest con for this game would be that its not a single-player game. You can play it alone but its not even half the fun.

So if you are looking for a coop game to have fun with your friends this game is for you.

reviewText: Forced is absolutely brutal, requiring constant team communication, clever problem solving and the mastery of combat skills. It can be an incredible amount of fun and is highly recommended for any group of gamer friends.This game pleasantly surprised me: simple in concept, but with an incredible amount of depth to it.I can’t stress enough how much fun Forced is when you’ve got even just one other player. It’s a smartly designed cooperative action game with a great variety in its challenges, and a great combat system that encourages teamwork over all else.Forced is an honest cooperative RPG with some good ideas suitable for 3 or 4 players but a hard nut to crack for lone wolves.Playing solo is oftentimes more frustrating than fun.However if you’re itching for a hardcore co-op action experience, then you’ve struck gold with Forced.

reviewText:
FORCED is an insanely fun co-op puzzle brawler. You play as a slave being trained up to be a gladiator and you are exposed to 25 challenging levels (5 bosses, 20 challenge rooms). After 30 hours of playing the game (it can definitely be completed MUCH faster), here's what I think..

Pros:

- The game is infinitely more fun with co-op partners. The difficulty fluctuates a lot depending on whether you do a challenge solo or with a group. For example, some challenge rooms are easier to do with more people. On the other hand, some boss rooms require a lot more concentration with a full group due to the higher amount of adds. Either way it is a game that does a great job of promoting teamwork seeing as the 4 available weapon-types have a specific role to fulfill.

- The skill variety is ample enough. There are 3 passive and active slots and there are enough skills for all types of situations.

- There is a large variety of different challenges rooms with various objectives. There are 4 acts (or areas) and all of the puzzles are different. No 2 puzzles repeat so you can be sure that the game stays 'fresh' until the end.

- You get to face challenging bosses. Each boss has a speed challenge and a 'self-imposed' handicap challenge. With these 2 challenges, you can't just face-smash your way to full-on victory. Fully completing a boss level requires a certain level of precision and understanding of the room's mechanisms.

- The spirit guide's dialogue is quite well-done. It was entertaining enough to get me through the entire game without getting complacent.


Cons:

- The Camera feels very limited.
- There is currently a glitch that sinks the 3rd player in any group under the floor when entering or re-entering the preparation room. They are currently looking into it.
- High latency can cause issues in some puzzles. These issues can block progression.

All in all I loved FORCED. I haven't had that much fun in co-op since playing Magicka.

I would like to see more puzzles in the future. The bosses were alright but the puzzles felt a lot more satisfying/rewarding when completed.

9/10 and looking forward to sequels and other releases from this developer!

reviewText:
Cooperative Action Puzzle RPG. You collect crystals throughout levels by beating them, and optionally, completing challenges. These crystals unlock active abilities, passive abilities, and slots for both active and passive abilities (up to 3 each). There are 4 varying classes you can choose from any time while in the hub. You can't have more than 1 class chosen at a time. My favorite class is Frozen Captain America.

It's got simple combat where you can dodge most enemy attacks with good timing, and puzzles involving an ethereal sphere dude you call to your position, that you can also carry with you. It's used by guiding it through shrines, which can have a healing, explosive, speed boost, etc, effect. You can also guide it to a block, which can be pushed and pulled to your location by calling it. You can also activate other things, like torches, as well as purify things and destroy enemy spawners.

The game has about 20+ something stages, and a challenging boss and new environments after every several stages.

It's a pretty difficult game, and I suggest you try it with at least one other person, or you'll probably go mad in solo.

reviewText:
Lots of fun. Great game for the casuals AND the hardcore gamers. It's a challenge even if you don't look to complete all the achievement ( I did...I got hooked...It's awesome ^^ ). You never stop improving and if you're up to the challenge, you're going to have loads of fun.

The adventure is great, with a steady learning curve. You get to learn how to play each of these four badasses if you feel like it or you can just go and solo one of them if you have a favourite, it's not impossible to finish the game if you do.

Bosses are sometimes a bit easy because the strats are quite simple to understand BUT most of them are still challenging because in this game, knowing what to do is the easy part, being able to do it is a whole other story.

If you have a trustworthy group of friends though, buy the fourpack, and solve these levels together. The more the merrier. Really. Especially since some of these levels take you by surprise : there's nothing funnier than seeing your friends panic and getting slaughtered in every side of the map because of some new content to the game ^^ (Beware of the fog !).

Finally, the new mode they added, survival mode, is a gem. The first levels are a bit easy to beat imo, compared to the rest of the game, but the last one is....evil. I can't imagine playing with 4 players in this last level, but I'm guessing it must be the funniest experience this game has to offer. You'll understand once you get there ^^
Also, there is a 'last man standing' level in these survival maps which seems pretty interesting and very promising in a way that I'll surely spend nights with my friends playing this level only and having fun helping/betraying your friends to survive the longest time possible =D.

Overall an incredible game for those who like puzzles, badass characters with skill trees and passive trees, and last but not least, a little bit of challenge, for a price that is, in my opinion way underappreciated.

reviewText:
The game is quite different from what I expected when I was buying it. It's not that much about puzzles or real combat skills (I imagined something like dodging at the right time, using different attacks per enemy weaknesses, combo-ing, etc). No, it's more about great cooperation between players (voice chat is an absolute must), selecting correct skills from the skill tree for that particular level, and, unfortunately, also about grinding. The game is quite hard, don't expect a casual multiplayer co-op game. You'll need to repeat every level many times to at least finish it. And then, you'll need to repeat it many times more in order to fulfill the challenge or time criteria. If you don't do it, you'll be very much underpowered in the later levels and the difficulty will go from high to insane.

So, the principle of the game is not to enjoy many different levels. The number or levels is quite low (25). The principle of the game is to rinse and repeat until you finish them perfectly. It's not what I expected and it's not what I enjoy, but tastes differ, I'm sure many people will like it. That's not why I'm giving it a thumbs down.

The thumbs down goes for technical execution. From technical level, this game is horrible. Network issues are extremely common - the game splits and people see different things on their screens, someone can't move at all, someone dies but gets stuck in the dying animation and glitches the level, unable to complete it, and the list goes on. But, that's not the worst thing. The worst thing is the camera. It deserves a paragraph on its own.

The camera. The devs had an idea that you need to see all characters at the same time, all the time. So if you go into different directions, the camera zooms out to make sure you see all characters. Questionably a good idea, with the worst implementation ever. First, this camera mode is mandatory, you can't switch between focused camera" (seeing just yourself in the center of the screen) and "overview camera" (seeing everyone). No

reviewText: Incredible game. Hits the right balance between these developers are evil!" and "holy crap I just pulled that off!". The four classes are well varied and the skill trees are very interesting. Toying with characters builds is quite fun. The story is simple but the early twist plus good characters and good voice actors make it engaging. Coop (and local coop!) makes this a great party game too. All that together and the result is a game I haven't been able to put down. I think about it when not playing and push for the "ok just one more unlock" when I am playing."

reviewText:
I played this game co-op with a friend. I have not tried single player. That said, the game was quite fun with one other person and requires a signifcant amount of teamwork to complete challenges and to fight bosses.

FORCED is an interesting take on the action rpg genre. Instead of running around solely fighting hordes of monsters, you have arenas that you must enter and complete challenges. You also have an NPC that you must guide around who is an integral part of completing these challenges, which usually involves calling him to particular locations, causing him to move over shrines or other objectives to complete objectives while monsters are there to get in the way and make things more difficult. I wouldn't go so far as to call these challenges puzzles, as it is usually pretty obvious what needs to be done and is more a matter of execution.

There are a panoply of abilities you can unlock to help you destroy monsters. They are unlocked by completing arenas, completing them quickly, and by doing special objectives in them. There are four classes and you are not tied to a particular one. You can change your class any time you are not in an arena and you will have the same tier of abilities unlocked on each character, so you don't have to level each one or anything like that.

The boss arenas are fun and each one has their own interesting set of mechanics. A few of the arenas and one of the boss fights in particular (the skeleton, for reference) are quite difficult, but that just makes beating them all the more satisfying.

So all in all, a fun game to play co-op. I'm not sure about the single player aspect of the game. Having had a multiplayer play through, I have no interest in going through a second run solo.

reviewText: Don't buy this game for its online multiplayer.  If you can even manage to connect to someone it's practically guaranteed that everyone will have crippling amounts of lag.  For a co-op oriented game all I can do is shake my head at this flaw.\n\nI really wanted to like this game as Gauntlet 64 on the (you guessed it) N64 was one of my favorite games of the time.  Also, Forced IS a fantastic game when it runs properly.  The puzzle component of the game adds some much needed spice" to the hack-n-slash genre and the arena design is fantastic.  The limited RPG components of the game worked just fine and allowed for some character customization
date: combined with the solid gameplay it's a recipe for success.\n\nIn the end
recommended:
none of the games' strengths matter when you can't even hop into an online co-op match and have fun with your friends (or strangers).

Don't even buy this when it's on sale if you want to game online with your friends.  You might as well flush the money down your toilet.  It's made even worse by how obviously solid the gameplay is when you play solo... such a shame!  A lot of TLC clearly went into this one but they messed up one crucial thing.

The devs can go on and on about how they are fixing it but that is total BS.  It should have worked right on release.  Selling a busted P.O.S. like this should be analagous to fraud."

reviewText:
A terrific game that allows up to 4 people to play.

I wouldn't recomend it while playing on your own though since that kinda defeats some of the purpose. Unlike other ARPGs or whatever we call these it's not focused around finding gear and leveling up. Instead each stage has a mission, a purpose. These are simple puzzles or annoying challenges that you need to find a plan on how to solve. It could be lasers, or bombs or just a simple kill everything mission". After a mission you are returned to a "world map" inbetween missions. You may change between 4 classes and 2 people can't be the same class. The classes act a little different and are good for different things.
In each mission you can earn 3 crystals
date: which is basically the leveling up system of the game. Once you reach a certain number of crystals you unlock additional skills you can use instead of the basic ones. How do you earn the crystals? It's a little different depending on the mission but mostly it's about clearing the mission within a certain time frame
recommended: not taking damage or doing something fancy.\n\nGreat game

reviewText:
Hypothetical situation you're a gladiator and spirits are always with you because you have a spirit mentor he's called Belfry or something. He has a mental disorder, so he's got multiple personalities and one of them is a capital arsehat. that's why you have to be a gladiator.
Once they establish the plot, you get to punch a scarecrow with a weapon and then you get to punch it REALLY hard and then you're a real gladiator. This is a good game to play with a controller. After you're a real gladiator, you have to go fight real enemies, and then you're a true gladiator. Once you do that, you can start playing actual levels, and then you can be acknowledged as a gladiator.
Levels are fun with friends, if you happen to have any. Friends are useful because they do everything wrong and will inevitably make the game harder. So don't try to play this with friends, they're usually really bad at this. If you do play with friends out of the kindness of your heart, it is not required that you acknowledge them as gladiators. You may opt to refer to them as peasent, commoner, or perhaps dead.

Fighting is fun because you pick a weapon and then you kill enemies with it. When you kill an enemy a few times, it loses health and gains marks instead. Marks are sort of like a currency in this game, where enemies can trade you their health points for more marks. Once they've made this trade, they can opt  to sell them to you in exchange for more damage. Through this method, you can kill enemies, and become a gladiator.

Becoming a gladiator is harder than just killing enemies though. you need to get crystals and stuff, and those let you get more abilities and passive things and active abilities and passive abilities, as well as skills which you acquire by collecting gems.
There is also a soundtrack in the game, although I do not remember any of it. It is probably gladiator music. I can not confirm this. I would give this game anywhere from 10 to 12 dollars, because I think it was on sale.
Now is a good time to buy it, since you can get it at full price again.

This is a definite must-have for anyone that thinks they might like to be a gladiator, in any sense of the word.

reviewText:

No level or gear grinding necessary, no getting stuck in skill trees, and the puzzle aspect force you to think about what else you are supposed to be doing while you hack'n'slash the incoming mobs...not just mindlessly stumbling into your objectives on a huge map.

The combat is structured well. The game description notes that ALL attacks are avoidable, which does allow you to focus on skillfully avoiding the enemies, rather than button mashing.

The game scales very well in multiplayer, and the connectivity is great so far.

This game? Buy this game.

reviewText:
Typically single player games have co-op features that aren't requirements to play and pass the game. FORCED on the other hand is a single player game that HAS TO BE played in co-op. The challenges scale so that if there are fewer players you may need to do a task fewer times or kill fewer enemies, but it's still challenges created with co-operative play in mind; you may need to carry a ball fewer times across the screen but you still need to carry it across the screen rather than alternating with a partner. There are four heroes, each specializing in different tasks and the game comes into its own when they're all working together taking advantage of their specialties. You can conceivably play this title single player but it's an experience meant for co-op. Preferably 3 people or more (max of 4).

Like any co-op experience FORCED spends little time in cutscenes or dialogue; there are 5 hubworlds you travel to in a small overworld map, each with 5 levels and a boss. Each level gives you a max of three crystals: one for completion, another for completing a challenge specific to that level, and a third for completion under a certain time.

It's a relatively short game if you're just aiming to pass levels and face the bosses. Despite that several levels and bosses present a WORTHY challenge and will require some coordination and strategizing on your teams' end. Otherwise length and replay value comes in trying to do the challenges and finishing the levels under the time limit. Many of the challenges further the co-op aspect by requiring some modicum of strategy in finishing them, whether that be lining up the shield hero so that he tanks hits whilst the archer attacks from afar so that no one on the team is hit by a particular enemy, or positioning heroes so that an explosive object doesnt touch enemies on its way to its objective in a timely manner. I don't know how its even possible to complete some of these tasks in single player.

The point in completing challenges is for crystals; attaining a certain amount unlocks more abilities for your class and/or slots to use abilities (maximum of three). The abilities are obviously different for each class, and they have their use depending on what you're trying to do. You can use one of your slots for a healing ability to aid your team in bossfights, or you can switch it out for a rapid fire attack to take out many smaller enemies that may present issues whilst the rest of your team is focusing a large enemy down. Pre-levels there's a moderate amount of strategy in synergizing heroes and abilities to get the job done.

Good and pretty short co-op experience, but that's the big thing: unless you have a group of people to play this with don't bother. It can be fun playing alone, but it's like playing payday or left4dead alone and without bots. It's made to be a co-op title and without it it isn't as enjoyable.

reviewText:
The bottom line?  FORCED has some issues, but it's well worth your time to play, especially if you can play with friends.

Upon starting FORCED, I faced some serious problems trying to get controllers working. Supposedly these issues have all been fixed now, so hopefully you won't suffer the same hassles.  Even if you do, however, I recommend you perservere and get it set up to play.

FORCED is first and foremost a puzzle game. Yes, the combat plays a significant part, and you will get good at the combat (and will need to), but the puzzles and the teamplay is what makes the game.  Trying to work out how to complete levels, and then complete the challenges and time trials is genuinely fun and will make you think and strategise, which is a really refreshing change of pace from so many other games.

Perhaps the biggest issues are the occasional bug that can make a level impossible, the aforementioned controller issues, and the skill unlock progression.  Some of the high levels skills unlocked later in the game are *really* underwhelming given the effort you've gone to acquire them, and the last unlock requires you to complete everything in order to obtain. That's right, you have to do everything in the game in order to unlock the last abilities, and even if they weren't hideously disappointing (which they are), that would leave you with nothing to do with that ability.

While FORCED enjoyable solo, I would most heartily recommend it as a fantastic game to play local co-op, I've read reports of issues with the net-code for playing with others online, but playing with multiple people on one screen is great.

I'd really love to see more from FORCED. I'd love to see more levels, and ideally some reworking of some of the skills available - there are a number that are basically useless.  Still, FORCED is well worth your money and your time.

reviewText:
In FORCED, you are.. FORCED to fight for your life alone or with friends, with up to 4 player co-op with 4 different classes.

In this game, you are tying to survive in challenges put on you by gods, made for their own enjoyment. You are helped by this soul to destroy them and free your people once and for all. In ages past, your race is alive only to fight and die for the entertainment of beings much more powerful than you. This will change.

The four classes available are very different in what they do, being very solid to the class they represent.
The first is ranged, using a bow and agility like abilities and based around lightning. Second, a strength based two handed class using fire and heavy but slow attacks. A rogue is the third, using fast attacks with evasion abilities. The last is a frost themed tank with defensive abilities and stuns to reduce the damage everyone in your party takes. You can choose between them whenever you want, in between levels and depending on what is needed.

The game is a mix of a hack and slash with puzzle elements, really focusing on teamwork when played with others. I found the gameplay boring by myself, but when I played with a friend it was much more enjoyable. It can be very difficult at times, requiring a very good amount of game sense to dodge certain abilities and do certain puzzles. The bosses are very well thought out, giving a nice end to each chapter. They are also very unforgiving.

The price is pretty high when not on sale, much too high for a game like this (its pretty short, being completed in around 8 hours) and I would recommend only getting it on sale. Make sure you get a friend who kinda knows what a hack and slash is, because its much more fun with another person, but having an inexperienced player makes it much much much more difficult.

Overall, 8 hours of gameplay, hack and slash gameplay with puzzle elements and four classes. Don't buy on full price, wait for a sale.

Personal Rating: 3/5

reviewText:
FORCED is, in my opinion, a masterful execution of skill-based action mechanics.

In ways I feel like it's a natural progression on the Gauntlet sort of hack-and-slash genre, combined with some MOBA/aRPG role elements into a highly skillful experience. The mark system encourages good team strategy and the ability to spec for each mission individually allows you to roll pretty strongly different combos to meet the needs of the levels.

My friend and I stayed up all night for a night and fully completed the game, every moment intense and completely capturing us.

FORCED deserves far more accolade. If fun, strong, and rewarding game mechanics come first in your book like they do for me, this game is right up your alley. It is the alley. It is the quintessential alley! Get it!

reviewText:
I wanted a game I could couch co-op with my girlfriend when we're in the mood for hack'n'slashing.
Forced covered this perfectly, but also turned out to be so much more. The puzzles weave through the action seamlessly, creating a challenging but exhilarating atmosphere. The necessary tactical reconsideration after being defeated multiple times means replaying levels doesn't get boring. The levelling system is a cruel but perfect motivator, pushing you to visit forgotten torturous levels in the hope for one more gem.
If you're playing by yourself, this will be a challenging but rewarding experience.
If you're playing with a friend, this will be a heap of fun, but may cause you to slap each other.

Very dissappointed the sequel will not be multiplayer.

reviewText: This game is really super crazy addictive fun. It can be played solo (at some points it feels like the challenges are easier solo). This isn't torchlight, though that's what it looks like. You're here to complete levels, sort of like minigames. Each level has 3 components - getting through it (completion), an achievement you have to complete along with the rest of the level (challenge) and a time attack (time). The more of these you complete, the more crystals you get which give you unlocks that you'll need - 1 crystal is basically 1 level for your characters. You can switch out characters on a per level/per retry basis, you're not locked into any one class, which is fantastic.

reviewText:
This is one of the few games in my Steam library that I have actually gotten my wife to play with me, so that gets it a positive review right there. But seriously this game is tons of fun. It's not exactly story-rich, but thats not really something you look for in this style of game. The four characters to pick from are a good representation of different play styles, and the variety of spells allow for some customization to that as well. The levels are more than just navigating through the map; the puzzles are very challenging at times, and the boss levels are actually tough. To me, those two points determine the success or failure of this style of game, and Forced is a winner in both categories.

Pros:
Challenging puzzles
Tough boss levels

Cons:
Thin story (but seriously, who cares about that? That's like complaining that the Dota 2 lore is weak.)

One more thing: go to BetaDwarf's site, and read about how while programming this game, they literally lived in part of a college that wasn't being used for almost a year before they got caught and kicked out! It's hilarious, and there's no way you won't buy the game after that. Better yet, buy the 4-pack and your friends will be FORCED to play with you!

reviewText:
I thought my friends and I made a great team. I thought we could tackle this game like a well oiled machine, just as we have with any other game.


No. I was wrong and for my arrogance I paid the price. But my friends and I are closer now for this game showed us the worst in eachother. Now our teamwork has skyrocketed.

This game is hard. It will challenge you mentally and socially. Your ability to communicate ideas on the flaw will be sharpened or you will fail. This is a top down RPG with a stronger focus on classes that play off eachother and not so much on customization. You play through a quick and easy tutorial and then are introduced to the main area where you will select which level you want to play, much like Crash Bandicoot 2: Cortext Strikes back. This game has a large focus on cohesion and team work and less on hacking and griding through hundreds of monsters. I strongly recommend this game because I have never had so much fun getting my ♥♥♥ kicked.

reviewText: Decent premise, unique gameplay mechanics, very tight controls plus co-op!  This is in the same vein as Magicka and Torchlight.  It has fewer bugs and much tighter controls than Magicka.  It is not nearly as deep in terms of skill tree etc as Torchlight and it is rather linear, but I do appreciate how the classes play off one another.  While torchlight will throw half a dozen usable skills at you which may do very similar things, FORCED lets you pick a couple skills and use them in what seems like a half dozen ways.  While I miss the stats of Torchlight, this is a very satisfying little game.  Get on sale if you can, but a thumbs up regardless.  8.5/10

reviewText:
Recommended for the great control and game mechanics. The controls are on par with, or even succeeds, the best in the genre (which would be Diablo III I suppose)... they are very snappy. Ok, maybe calling the orb to your location could be smoother, that is the only thing I don't like.

FORCED differs itself from every other ARPG by not having any grinding... and also not having equipment or experience points. If this is good or bad, I don't know, but it makes for a different game.

You unlock abilities by completing trials. Each trial is a level with monsters and sometimes puzzles.
You get one point for completing the level.
You get one point for completing the level within a specified amount of time, and
you get one point for completing a unique challenge for each level.

However, by not having the grind, there is a burden on the developers to provide a lot more content than normally in the genre. You finish each area much faster, and there is no value for the player in going back once the trials are completed... and the amount of content is OK, but not great.

reviewText: Forced is a great ARPG game that features 4 classes. Each class has different unlockable passive and active abilities.  You collect Gems  by completing various tasks within each level and that's how you level up in the game. You play as gladiators (the Storm Bow, the Volcanic Hammer, the Spirit Knives and the Frost Shield) who try to find their freedom and are aided by a spirit called Balfus. Balfus and the fact that you can use him by calling him toward you, lighting torches (and some other things) is the main reason this game stands out as it adds some great and diverse tactics that always serve towards your goal of earning the 3 Gems each level (arena) has to offer. The story is not this game's strong point as the plot is fairly simple. You play as a gladiator that has been FORCED (pun intended) to fight in arenas and Balfus guides you through it and you ultimately have to become a free man.\nAll in all the game is really tactical and has a lot of strategic depth, granted you want to 100% it with friends.\nThe multiplayer is really fun and I recommend you get 3 or 4 friends to play with. The game provides great puzzles and fun combat and with good co-operation it's bound to be a truly fun experience! I thoroughly recommend it!

reviewText: This was a failed attempt to merge 3 different genres: RPG, Top down hack-and-slash, and co-op puzzle solving. Its claim to fame is that players are supposed to cooperate in puzzle solving while being assaulted by waves of enemies. However, these systems work against each other. The AI enemies are not threatening enough to pose as a threat; they become a mere annoyance as you try to solve the puzzles to finish the level. Likewise, the co-op puzzles aren't very good either; instructions and tutorials are vague, but if you manage to guess-and-check your way to the solution, you'll find many levels that repeat the same type of puzzle. The co-op system doesn't really work with puzzles; you'll be fighting your friends for your idea of problem solving, instead of collaborating to complete the challenge. Connectivity is horrid, and although the game features 4 different classes, they feel somewhat similar against the same dull foes. 3/10

reviewText:
Pros:
-Rewards skillful play a lot
-The right game if you are the type of player who likes challenging himself with speed trials etc
-Lots of different playstyles, through the 4 classes and the skill customisation
-The Spirit Mentor is really fun once you get a hang of it, especially in co-op. A lot of cool mechanics via this, such as having to cleverly position the mentor in order to avoid being damaged continuously from a sandstorm.

Cons:
-If you are the type of player who likes to progress via character power, rather than personal skill, this is not a game for you
-Can be a bit hard to get a hang of the Spirit Mentor mechanic

Disclaimer:
The majority of my playtime with this game has been in the standalone beta client, and thus there might be changes I am unaware of, and also, do not trust the hours played" listed for me."

reviewText:
FORCED has made my buddy and I quite happy.
It feels like the developers had fun making the game, and it shows.

The gameplay is very reminiscent of Gauntlet: Legends:
+isometric camera
+hack and slash combat
+'level up' system in unlocking new skills
+fast and well paced

+The campaign is a little cheesy, but charming in it's own way

-graphics aren't impressive
+but it makes the game easy to run
+and the art direction more than makes up for it

+inspired and creative puzzles keep you thinking, but don't slow the game down enough to where you're bored and feel you're in a puzzle-only game.

You're constantly working out defeating small waves of monsters, dancing around the map's pitfalls, and working out how to solve puzzles.

-some of the challenges can be tedius and seem unresponsive, though it's more an issue of getting used to hit boxes and mechanics.

I strongly recommend this game to small groups of friends who are looking for a fun and challenging multiplayer game.

9/10

reviewText:
Forced is one of the best unity games ever made. an enjoyable coop game with some fairly difficult challenges and enjoyable combat.

-pros: Sound and music
A plethera of interesting settings and objectives
Some tough and unique bosses
Good voice acting for what little there is
Spirit Mentor mechanics
Combat and progression are fun and encourage you to be creative
Local Coop

-cons: The rogue and archer classes are far better than shield and hammer
Some of the completion times use to get crystals for new abilities are somewhat impossible to get
Playing with the M&K after an hour and a half or so starts lagging the game
no pvp

It's still one of the best coop games to pick up and i would recommend to anyone.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Been playing this with my girlfriend, her sister and a friend of ours. It's pretty awesome, not gonna lie.

The game is pretty hard sometimes, but it's really fun. More than half of us 4 are impatient ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s when something doesn't go our way and we still have a lot of fun playing it.

The puzzles start out as the easiest thing ever and they quickly shift into something really weird. But pretty awesome.
The combat isn't the best ever, but it's definitely not bad. It's the mix of both that makes this a really fun title.

If I had to rate it, based on a limited amount of playtime, I'd say 8/10.


I haven't played it by myself, or with only 1 or 2 people so I can't say for those groups. But 4 players is really fun. Especially if people start getting confused with who is who. Not sure how they do it but 2 of our group tend to do that, and in some levels you can't get out of a certain area or you take massive damage, and they'd just randomly venture out and die. Or think they're someone else and walk into a huge laser. It's pretty entertaining.

I'd say the main reason why my rating isn't higher than 8 is because I thought there'd be a bit more puzzle-based levels. Or longer levels. Don't get me wrong, I don't mind short levels. But I find that co-op games are best when thrown into puzzle environments. Games like Trine 2, Battleblock Theater, Portal 2, Tiny Brains etc are great examples of that. (BBT isn't as much puzzle-based but you get the idea).

So it's mostly just my opinion really. I haven't seen any huge cons yet, quite a few pros, and the game was crazy cheap during the sale, 100% worth it(7.50$ for a 4pack, 2.50$ per individual game) and that's Canadian money. And our money isn't worth much lately, so you know that's a pretty decent deal.

Anyway, I've talked long enough, eh? Sorry for taking all of your time if you read all this. I have to go since the dam behind my house made of poutine and maple syrup let through a family of moose... ... ...s? Is it mooses? Or just moose? Or is it Meese? That sounds like it's so wrong. But at the same time so many moose" sounds just as wrong. I'll go with mooses. I like the sound of it. Doesn't feel right either but I like saying mooses.

TL;DR
I'm Canadian
Game is fun
Family of mooses
8/10
Co-op

reviewText:
It was a lot of fun, and a good Gauntlet substitute. It's got a few signature and interesting game mechanics that make sure the puzzle solving difficulty is never boring. There's a decent amount of unlockable abilitied that make the gameplay fresh for as long as it takes to beat the game.

Other than that, the game is a little shallow and the voice acting and storytelling is comically horrid. In my opinion, that's a not a big deal, and it's made up for in gameplay. Once you finish the game, you will be finished. It's nice that you can always access all of the classes, but there is no replay value.

I'd only get this if you had friends you know would play with you and if you're really into the puzzle solving, fast paced, isometric dungeon crawler games.

reviewText:
Been playing this with my girlfriend, her sister and a friend of ours. It's pretty awesome, not gonna lie.

The game is pretty hard sometimes, but it's really fun. More than half of us 4 are impatient ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s when something doesn't go our way and we still have a lot of fun playing it.

The puzzles start out as the easiest thing ever and they quickly shift into something really weird. But pretty awesome.
The combat isn't the best ever, but it's definitely not bad. It's the mix of both that makes this a really fun title.

If I had to rate it, based on a limited amount of playtime, I'd say 8/10.


I haven't played it by myself, or with only 1 or 2 people so I can't say for those groups. But 4 players is really fun. Especially if people start getting confused with who is who. Not sure how they do it but 2 of our group tend to do that, and in some levels you can't get out of a certain area or you take massive damage, and they'd just randomly venture out and die. Or think they're someone else and walk into a huge laser. It's pretty entertaining.

I'd say the main reason why my rating isn't higher than 8 is because I thought there'd be a bit more puzzle-based levels. Or longer levels. Don't get me wrong, I don't mind short levels. But I find that co-op games are best when thrown into puzzle environments. Games like Trine 2, Battleblock Theater, Portal 2, Tiny Brains etc are great examples of that. (BBT isn't as much puzzle-based but you get the idea).

So it's mostly just my opinion really. I haven't seen any huge cons yet, quite a few pros, and the game was crazy cheap during the sale, 100% worth it(7.50$ for a 4pack, 2.50$ per individual game) and that's Canadian money. And our money isn't worth much lately, so you know that's a pretty decent deal.

Anyway, I've talked long enough, eh? Sorry for taking all of your time if you read all this. I have to go since the dam behind my house made of poutine and maple syrup let through a family of moose... ... ...s? Is it mooses? Or just moose? Or is it Meese? That sounds like it's so wrong. But at the same time so many moose" sounds just as wrong. I'll go with mooses. I like the sound of it. Doesn't feel right either but I like saying mooses.

TL;DR
I'm Canadian
Game is fun
Family of mooses
8/10
Co-op

reviewText:
Forced is one of the best unity games ever made. an enjoyable coop game with some fairly difficult challenges and enjoyable combat.

-pros: Sound and music
A plethera of interesting settings and objectives
Some tough and unique bosses
Good voice acting for what little there is
Spirit Mentor mechanics
Combat and progression are fun and encourage you to be creative
Local Coop

-cons: The rogue and archer classes are far better than shield and hammer
Some of the completion times use to get crystals for new abilities are somewhat impossible to get
Playing with the M&K after an hour and a half or so starts lagging the game
no pvp

It's still one of the best coop games to pick up and i would recommend to anyone.

reviewText:
5.5/10 This game is only just on the recommend side.

The public games are a severe lack. There's no hot-join functionality, which means if people are trying to join in on a game they will interrupt the one already taking place.

When playing co-op the progress is limited to the person who has the least, and not the hosts - this does not encourage players who are father ahead to stop op and play coop, when they have to play the same levels over with the same abilities.

The movement with k/m is aweful. In most levels the best ways to move is diagonal and even between the 16 directions that keyboards offers. Without a joystick some levels require very a lot of focus on movement.

Soloing is possible but feels overly complicated and difficult. The mechanics of the levels stay the same no matter the number of players, only the number of foes are affected.

reviewText:
Pros:
-Rewards skillful play a lot
-The right game if you are the type of player who likes challenging himself with speed trials etc
-Lots of different playstyles, through the 4 classes and the skill customisation
-The Spirit Mentor is really fun once you get a hang of it, especially in co-op. A lot of cool mechanics via this, such as having to cleverly position the mentor in order to avoid being damaged continuously from a sandstorm.

Cons:
-If you are the type of player who likes to progress via character power, rather than personal skill, this is not a game for you
-Can be a bit hard to get a hang of the Spirit Mentor mechanic

Disclaimer:
The majority of my playtime with this game has been in the standalone beta client, and thus there might be changes I am unaware of, and also, do not trust the hours played" listed for me."

reviewText:
You should play this game if
-you like skillbased co-op games that provides a challenge
-you are looking for an awesome game to play with friends (great for LAN parties)
-you prefer crisp controls that gives maximum freedom (play with mouse/keyboard/gamepad whatever you fancy)
-you enjoy making tactical plans for challenging encounters
-you take pride in being good at the games you set out to play

You should NOT play this game if
-you prefer grinding games where you can grind your way out of challenges
-you don't like trying multiple attemps on a difficult encounter
-you don't enjoy having a laugh with your friends
-you don't like the fact that sometimes you need to becomie good at a game in order to beat it

reviewText: One of the better co-op games I've played. Definitely the best co-op indie game I've played. So awesome, in fact, that everyone I play it with avoids continuing to play with me! I get way too into it. But it held interest for my wife and I and a friend of ours for about 20 hours of gameplay before they didn't want to listen to my ♥♥♥♥ anymore, so that's saying something. Honestly, though, the element of interacting with each other via using the orb to interact with the environment in order to navigate the map and defeat creatures and bosses... it's ingenious (I realize that was a confusing sentence but perhaps it helps properly emphasize the complexity of the game). This game gets a solid 9.5/10. It would get a 10/10 if I could find the right friends to finish the game with! I really want to beat it!

reviewText:
I can't speak to how this game plays in a co-op setting, as of July 2014, there is no one left playing this game anymore - but I can speak to its single-player campaign.

This game is simply not fun if you play by yourself.   Everything is balanced for multiple players, after the first couple trials, the game simply becomes tedious if you're trying to do everything on your own.

While I appreciate a good challenge, this game focuses on the wrong place.  The puzzles are brain-dead easy, and the single-player challenge simply comes from throwing an ever-increasing amount of mobs at you.   If it was possible to out-run these enemies and kite their numbers down, it would be manageable, but as they all move faster than you and, in many levels, respawn faster than you can kill them it makes the singleplayer game completely unenjoyable.

reviewText:
I am really surprised this game is rated this well.

It has a lot of issues. Game for one is extremely difficult, but in the wrong way. A lot of anti fun mechanics, such as enemy attacks slowing you down.

It has also been pretty buggy, have had frame rate drops and slight freezes, and this is on a semi decent computer.

This single player seems way too easy, because I think you have infinite lives, as long as you don't die every 30 seconds.

Meanwhile, in online play, it seems the complete oppisite, and very difficult to even get passed the first boss.

The online/co-op game play requires a next level mindset, to all be able to equally control the ball on which the game is based around.

Overall, I'd rather throw away the money spent on this game, then buy this game again. Do not buy, buy a good game, like Sprial Knights instead, oh wait, that games free. HMM.

reviewText:
Refreshingly challenging and enjoyable.  The class and level designs are very well tuned for the sake of being challenging.  Each class has its own unique playstyle, and several builds to try and play around.  The level design clearly shows how much effort the developers put into this game because each and every single level is unique, and even unique with respect to the number of players.

Don't worry about the difficulty.  I guarantee you can SOLO clear every challenge with only trial and error in game. (Yes, I have done that myself, without using any guide.)  Everything is managable if you know what you need to do and what you are doing.  Analyze the level, plan your action, customize your character build, then execute it with, um, some reflex.

I truly recommend this game.  It has been so long since I last enjoy action/puzzle game this much, especially in multiplayer mode.

reviewText: My advice: DO NOT buy this game. The description is misleading: there is no RPG element to this game. Nor is singleplayer actually possible, despite it being an option: you simply cannot complete many of the challenges. All it is a coop puzzle arena, and even that I would not mind if the coop worked. It does not. Well, it does for a while, but if you get more than, say, 20 enemies onscreen at one time, something breaks in the game's netcode and everyone who is not hosting suddenly gets massive lag. Looks like GPU lag almost. So we tried different host. Same thing, the host always seeing the game fine, the guests getting 1-5 FPS during intense fights.\n\nTL:DR This is a multiplayer only game that does not support multiplayer, avoid at all cost.

reviewText:
Forced is a neat little Action RPG puzzle couch co-op game. Maybe a cross between DotA/LoL + WoW + Portal 2. In short you are solving puzzles in a dungeon/instances with your partner while mobs attack you.

Imagine sitting together with your 360 controllers (or on skype) running around avoiding a laser beam while trying to kill mobs that are attacking you. Meanwhile your co-op partner is aligning Balfus (a floating orb) in a straight line towards you and screaming at you to pull the orb so that it goes through a shrine that stops a deadly mists that is slowly filling the dungeon. You pull the orb towards you but just when the orb is about to turn off the the mist your co-op partner gets pinned by a mob he didn't avoid and needs to call the orb back to him to free himself. Now the mist is out of control and your coop partner is low on health. This is a basic scenario in Forced.

The game has several dungeons/levels that you have to complete. Each dungeon rewards a total of 3 crystals. One for completing the dungeon, one for a speed/timed run and one for completing with a special requirement (e.g no healing, not getting hit by a special mob, etc).

Before each dungeon you choose to play one of four available classes. A warrior, rogue, hunter and a tank. Every class has two talent trees: One tree for active talents and one for passive talents. As you earn more crystals you unlock more of your talents.  You get to choose 3 active and 3 passive skills. That means that you have 4 buttons to press: One for basic attack and three for active talents.

This is a game where you can play competitvely and min/max what class and what spec to play for eac dungeon. make a tactic and practice exucuting it impeccably or you can grab a 360 controller and have fun with your girlfriend on the couch.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I bought this with a friend, and we had a blast. The payoff here is great; I received immense satisfaction from figuring out puzzles and performing insanely powerful attacks by coordinating with someone else. I firmly believe the best way to experience FORCED is with a dedicated partner or three so that you can complete the entire game with the same group of people.

That being said, the puzzles are not very complicated at all. The true difficulty will be in attempting Challenges (finishing a level while achieving a specific goal) and Time Trials (finishing a level within a certain amount of time). Completing Challenges and Time Trials will require attempt after attempt after attempt. Beta Dwarf could have planned for this a bit better and not put as many long cut scenes in inconvenient places, but you can skip after a few seconds. Nevertheless, Challenges and Time Trials give this title some serious replayability. The game is fun enough to justify multiple (read: dozens of) consecutive attempts. I did not feel like I had completed the game until I had all 75 gems, which took roughly 47 hours.

The online infrastructure can be a little rough. We had to exit out of the game and set it back up once every 1-1.5 hours or so due to game crashing bugs or unresponsive controls. However, it is important to note that the gameplay made it worth it. We kept coming back to it because of the addictive gem collecting and the fun, rewarding combat system. Mercifully, Beta Dwarf has insured that load times are minimal and creating/joining a game are very simple. This means setting up a game is a trivial affair, and the inconvenience of the (infrequent) game crashing bugs is mitigated.

The combat system is the crux of the gameplay. Basic attacks leave enemies with marks. Depending on what abilities your character has, marks can cause special attacks to do more damage.
The abilities you equip your character with (up to 3 active and 3 passive) give you perks and access to powerful attacks. Discovering synergy between passives and actives is one of the most compelling reasons to keep playing the game and adds strategy to what would otherwise be a mindless beat-em-up.
Gems enable you to unlock abilities and equip yourself with more abilities. There are 75 in the game, three for each level (1 for beating the level, 1 for completing the challenge, 1 for beating the Time Trial). Every few gems you score, you unlock a new ability, which adds to the sense of progress throughout the game and encourages you to experiment with your new found awesomeness.


It is important to note that the experience I am praising arose from me from having a friend that was dedicated to playing the game. I cannot speak to the game's singleplayer mode, but I also cannot see it providing the same sense of accomplishment, nor can I see it motivating me in the same way to attempt each level the insane number of times I did. It always helped to have someone to talk to and discuss strategies with. With that understood, I give it...

8.7/10

I hope Beta Dwarf keeps making awesome multiplayer games with over-the-top bosses.

TL;DR : Great gameplay, adequate online connectivity, don't get it if you don't have friends.

reviewText: Forced is a neatly polished game which will bring a couple of hours of fun with you and your friends. At first the game teaches you the simple mechanics as you learn each of the classes. As you progress into the next world, the game does get harder, with enemies being tougher and puzzles more challenging, but as you master that world, the next is even more difficult, where you and your friends have to work very hard to complete each challenge. Has a very nice levelling and upgrade system, could use some work, balancing, etc. The only problem I have, is Singleplayer and Multiplayer difficulty scaling. Want to play past the second world by yourself? Well that is near impossible. I am not sure if this has been fixed yet, but BetaDwarf should consider to make the game easier (lower enemy spawns, health, damage, etc.) when by yourself. Also I've noticed an uneven scaling with two to three to four players. I believe three is the easiest. Other than that you'll probably snag a good 5-20 hours based on how much you enjoy it, and if you have a small group of friends this is a great game to spend those hours together. Everything is polished, the graphics, the sound, which has exceptional music. 7.5/10, would be a 9/10 if made easier for singleplayer.

reviewText:
Great game at a great price!  I've read some reviews that the co-op isn't playable, however I've only played the single player/campaign mode and find the game excellent!

Forced combines Diablo-type hack & slash with some very unique puzzles and difficult challenges. The casual player could try and hack & slash their way through the game, but for more hardcore gamers there are times to beat and challenges to conquer on every stage which require a lot more thinking and strategy.  Another great feature is that most levels usually take under 5 minutes which make this a great game to sit down to if you don't have hours and hours to play.

This is a really well made indie game that I'd say competes with the big market games.  In fact, I bought Diablo 3: Reaper of Souls about the same time as this and haven't touched D3 since.

reviewText:
The game's not rock solid just yet, and still crashes every so often, but so far version 1.2 has remained stable during a level (which is the most important thing). This is TONES better than 1.1 which crashed randomly all the time.

I still have a few issues which prevent me from giving it a stamp of recommended:

- As far as I can tell, you can't re-assign buttons on the controller. It would be nice to use a D-pad instead of the sticks.

- Still crashes every so often, which isn't a problem in any other games I've played.

- So far, I can only get local co-op to work with 1 gamepad, and 1 keyboard+mouse. It would be nice to have both players on game pads.

Things are starting out slowly, which I hope pick up soon, with larger areas and more variety in combat. Other than that, so far the game-play is good. There's a good balance for single screen co-op (single screen, wepon loadout, tightly focused levels), and the spirit ball mechanic is a good team-building idea even though at first it seemed like a bit of a gimmic.

reviewText:
2013/11/01三人COOPにてプレイ、約7～8時間。(シングルは未プレイ)
スクリーンショットではハクスラめいた構図ですが、トレハンの要素はなく、若干の成長要素があるものの純粋なアクションパズルゲーム。
個人的にはMagicaにBlizzardイズムを合わせたようなゲームと感じました。

プレイヤーは4種のRoleを選択し、しゃべる珠Balfusと協力しながら各Levelをクリアしていきます。
各Role共通のシステムとしてMarker(コンボポイント)があり、上手く蓄積とフィニッシュを織り交ぜることで敵を殲滅していきます。
戦闘バランス自体は絶妙で、各Roleの特徴をしっかり活かしてカバーしあわないと割とあっさり死にます……

バカゲーかと思いきやかなりしっかりと作られたゲームで高評価ですが、ラスボスが機能停止するバグと一部リトライ時に3Pが地面に埋まるバグがマイナス。
メインテーマとラスボスのBGMはかなりアツイ。

個人的評価
ゲーム性　　  85点
ストーリー　 　70点
BGM　 　　　70点
コスパ　　　  55点
バグや謎仕様-15点
総合評価　　 70点(意外な良作、バグや謎仕様が惜しい)

以下各Role
-赤(ハンマー)
MeleeのAoEやAuraがウリのパワーファイター。一定時間溜めることで強力なスイングができるが、移動スキルや脱出スキルが乏しい。
-青(盾)
ChargeやAoEStunを得意とする。一定時間毎にShieldがあがり攻撃をBlockできるようになるが、殲滅力に欠けるTankタイプ。
-緑(ダガー)
素早い攻撃とフィニッシュムーブの回転率で単体ダメージを叩き出す純粋なDPSタイプ。軽快な挙動も魅力。
-黄(弓)
得物通りの遠距離型。チャージショットや設置型のHeal、ChannelAoEなど強力な攻撃手段を持つ。

reviewText: So bought this game as a 4 pack with some friends. Totally worth it! It's a sorta hack/slash rpg'ish puzzle game. You control 1 of 4 different characters (hammer, bow, shield, daggers) each has their own set of skills, passives, and playstyles. You work with your friends to navigate innovative maps and figure out puzzles all with the help of a little orb spirt guy. Every person can call this orb to their position so it can be trolly if everyone is spamming. It requires a great deal of communication as it sometimes requires you to bounce the orb from person to person but without letting it hit objects (part of the puzzle). I highly recommend you pick this up in a 4 pack and play with friends over voice chat as it can be very fun, quirky, rewarding, and frustrating all in one but there is sense of accomplishment similar to when you first beat a boss in an MMO when you nail a puzzle while 3 of your friends are dead and you are teetering on life. The simple combat systems works perfectly as there is plenty of other object happening on the screen to keep you active and always thinking.\n\nThere isn't a game out there like this on the market that I am aware. Anyone who plays with friends should pick this up.

reviewText:
Introduction:
The Story behind this game is about a town of humans who spend their lives training and work for the God. Throughout the year they send warriors from their village to go deep into the realms to battle the guardians and try to defeat them, but none prevailed. After a long await four warriors came forth from the villages and started to slay the Guardians as one god tries to guide them through the realms or chaos. As the Warriors it's your destiny to send them to the right path.

Graphics:
Throughout the game the graphics for this game have been great quality and had had some amazing sceneries, not a lot is need to play this game and with a lot more room for improvement I wouldn't put any bad remarks towards this game just yet, with the design and the equipment, to the boss and bad guys. The game shows the player it can be like WoW and Rift, full of imagination and fantastic detail in the structures

Game play:
The game play in this game was very easy to understand, with the first few levels explain how certain objects word, the game challenges you through the levels, making sure you are fully aware of what certain things do and how to stop them. The game is based on a third person play and you can roam around the game with either a keyboard and mouse or a Controller.  for those who are PC gamers keyboard and mouse was easier for the bow master, but I personally liked the controller because of close combat so try and find something that'll suit your style. I play Volcanic Hammer and controller was my thing, but when it came to bow I had to switch.
The detail in the inventory and explanation were simple and this is what a game need as for beginner people feel comfortable knowing what's going on throughout the start and not be pressured and button mash. Each character has different abilities and fighting styles, if you read the spoiler then you understand what I mean. But try and find the right warrior for you and play with him till you get used to his abilities and powers.

Advantages:
This is one of the funniest Coop RPG games I played, with me and my mates we flied through the levels and got more excited as the game went on, the boss and ideas that were put into the puzzles were genius, as well as hard.
this game is good at both Single player and Coop. with coop play the game is at its best, you can roam and fight and work together to counter every possible bad guys and boss, but they also help you with strategies as all weapons will be in your arsenal so go and find the best ways to different each level.

Disadvantages:
As much as I love this game, there are a few bugs and downers on this game, one of them is the servers, through the game it won’t let you access other servers or game plays when you play coop, also when you host a game is sometimes freezes the game and closes the game down, making you restart from your last checkpoint, luckily this doesn't erase you data and you keep all you equipment, but this will frustrate you big time, even if your near completion or in the middle of a boss battle.

Overall:
I believe that even though this game has a lot of problems with it, I'm going to give it faith and say it's still a great game, the Developer is personally speaking to me and with anyone else who is in trouble and will help you throughout the game. For now I will give this game a 6/10 due to the bugs, but I recommend this game in the future.  With the designers fixing every problem and working hard on the patches this game will be a major success in the future. So don't get dishearted just yet. With the future patches I believe this game can hit 9.5/10 in my books as long as the serves get fixed and the game play continues.

Thanks you for reading and peace out :)

reviewText:
TLDR at the bottom

This will be my first and a fairly short review that hopefully gets the good points of this game across. This game is awesome. It is an indie game that will test your friendships on the highest level. It plays similar to diablo, with the need for reflexes like you're playing an FPS, and the mindpower for puzzle game. The thing that I found most pleasing in this game is the difficulty.

In the past (NES/SNES/Sega) there was no difficulty level, you just dealt with what they gave you. This game can be done the easy way and still have a good time, but if you choose to go the hard route... the game will make you cry. This game is so pleasingly unforgiving and the developers as well. Having met a few I love their mentality towards the game and makes me a happy owner.

For the people complaining about the problems. BF4, Skyrim, CoD or any other AAA title that had bugs up the yin yang and still people applauded how amazing it was. Not to say those games aren't good and that the bugs weren't fixed but why is an indie developer somehow excluded from being forgiven when they fix the bugs.

-
The game is a lot of fun, developers are awesome people with an awesome story, they actively attempt to fix bugs, challenging as heck, SPIRIT BLADES 4 LYFE!

reviewText:
2013/11/01三人COOPにてプレイ、約7～8時間。(シングルは未プレイ)
スクリーンショットではハクスラめいた構図ですが、トレハンの要素はなく、若干の成長要素があるものの純粋なアクションパズルゲーム。
個人的にはMagicaにBlizzardイズムを合わせたようなゲームと感じました。

プレイヤーは4種のRoleを選択し、しゃべる珠Balfusと協力しながら各Levelをクリアしていきます。
各Role共通のシステムとしてMarker(コンボポイント)があり、上手く蓄積とフィニッシュを織り交ぜることで敵を殲滅していきます。
戦闘バランス自体は絶妙で、各Roleの特徴をしっかり活かしてカバーしあわないと割とあっさり死にます……

バカゲーかと思いきやかなりしっかりと作られたゲームで高評価ですが、ラスボスが機能停止するバグと一部リトライ時に3Pが地面に埋まるバグがマイナス。
メインテーマとラスボスのBGMはかなりアツイ。

個人的評価
ゲーム性　　  85点
ストーリー　 　70点
BGM　 　　　70点
コスパ　　　  55点
バグや謎仕様-15点
総合評価　　 70点(意外な良作、バグや謎仕様が惜しい)

以下各Role
-赤(ハンマー)
MeleeのAoEやAuraがウリのパワーファイター。一定時間溜めることで強力なスイングができるが、移動スキルや脱出スキルが乏しい。
-青(盾)
ChargeやAoEStunを得意とする。一定時間毎にShieldがあがり攻撃をBlockできるようになるが、殲滅力に欠けるTankタイプ。
-緑(ダガー)
素早い攻撃とフィニッシュムーブの回転率で単体ダメージを叩き出す純粋なDPSタイプ。軽快な挙動も魅力。
-黄(弓)
得物通りの遠距離型。チャージショットや設置型のHeal、ChannelAoEなど強力な攻撃手段を持つ。

reviewText: Story: Kinda Bland. You are a man from a tribe of slaves bred for gladiator combat under watch of the gods." Cause you know
date:
women weren't EVER GLADIATORS! (history fail)
Gameplay:

-Puzzles; makes my brain hurt in a good way.

Humor: Not bad at all.
AND YET with all I've said: The game is super fun."

reviewText: So bought this game as a 4 pack with some friends. Totally worth it! It's a sorta hack/slash rpg'ish puzzle game. You control 1 of 4 different characters (hammer, bow, shield, daggers) each has their own set of skills, passives, and playstyles. You work with your friends to navigate innovative maps and figure out puzzles all with the help of a little orb spirt guy. Every person can call this orb to their position so it can be trolly if everyone is spamming. It requires a great deal of communication as it sometimes requires you to bounce the orb from person to person but without letting it hit objects (part of the puzzle). I highly recommend you pick this up in a 4 pack and play with friends over voice chat as it can be very fun, quirky, rewarding, and frustrating all in one but there is sense of accomplishment similar to when you first beat a boss in an MMO when you nail a puzzle while 3 of your friends are dead and you are teetering on life. The simple combat systems works perfectly as there is plenty of other object happening on the screen to keep you active and always thinking.\n\nThere isn't a game out there like this on the market that I am aware. Anyone who plays with friends should pick this up.

reviewText: Uppers: Intense, surprisingly intricate action co-op that works with three or four players and has a clever push-pull teamwork gimmick. In its best moments is like doing a really good raid in an MMO but without the hassle and poopsocking. Difficulty can be fine-tuned by doing challenges or choosing particular classes (eg no archer for Graw).\nDowners: Some strange performance issues - sometimes stutters a lot for no obvious reason, which can be a death sentence. Understandably cheap feeling to the presentation. Possibly a bit short. You will curse Balfus' name.\nThe Bottom Line: Co-op improves any video game, and FORCED uses it in an effective, rather innovative way. It's tough but rarely frustrating, and features satisfying/comical teamwork. Grab your mic and fight the spitters.

reviewText: Uppers: Intense, surprisingly intricate action co-op that works with three or four players and has a clever push-pull teamwork gimmick. In its best moments is like doing a really good raid in an MMO but without the hassle and poopsocking. Difficulty can be fine-tuned by doing challenges or choosing particular classes (eg no archer for Graw).\nDowners: Some strange performance issues - sometimes stutters a lot for no obvious reason, which can be a death sentence. Understandably cheap feeling to the presentation. Possibly a bit short. You will curse Balfus' name.\nThe Bottom Line: Co-op improves any video game, and FORCED uses it in an effective, rather innovative way. It's tough but rarely frustrating, and features satisfying/comical teamwork. Grab your mic and fight the spitters.

reviewText:
This turns out to be a 'puzzle fighting' style game.  Each individual challenge tends to be fairly well crafted with tricks and particular paths that are easier or harder.  Although it has a leveling system, the challenge based experience can leave you feeling stuck, and there is no actual grinding that can be done to unstick you.

Even so, failing the occasional stuck feeling, the game is enjoyable and worth a try.  I have been unable to actually land a multiplayer game (friends played at a different time than I did, and randoms never accept multiplayer requests), so can't really comment on that experience other than to say if you didn't bring your own friends with you, you probably won't be playing this way.

Challenging, with interesting mechanics and good overall quality.

Give it a try.

reviewText:
FORCED (Slightly Better Edition) is a fun combat/strategy multiplayer game with up to 3 friends, and I recommend it!

+ Combat is fast-paced and simple, with enough difference in the enemies' approaches to keep it engaging.
+ Puzzle elements CHALLENGE players to work together and think through obstacles.
+ Different elemental archtypes to choose from (ice, earth, fire, air) with multiple skill choices to equip as you level up.

- Occasionally blindsides the players with problems that require trial and error (or pure luck) to solve.
- Puzzles become frustrating without good communication and coordination between teammates.
- Low replayability.

reviewText:
Played with a full 4 players, and while it was fun at first, the puzzle elements quickly became too fiddly and the overall level of difficulty too great.

The main puzzle mechanic is that there is a companion character who is basically a glowing ball, which you move around only by calling it to where you are currently standing with a button press; in this way it will only move point to point in straight lines.  Moving the ball over various level objects actives them; you flip switches, move crates, and activate temporary buffs for your character this way.  However the problem is that you have to be quite precise with these movements; the ball is often quite small in relation to the screen and must move exactly over the thing you want to active.  This demands far too much precision in a game where you're often trying to focus on combat at the same time, and dealing with an isometric camera that is frequently zooming out to fit all characters on screen.  If the ball had a larger radius of activation, it would go a long way to making the game more entertaining than frustrating.

The level of precision required is the main source of the game's excessive difficulty.  The combat by itself is reasonable, but almost everything after the first set of levels requires managing the ball to solve puzzles while fighting at the same time and the game isn't rewarding enough to make investing the effort feel worth it.
