reviewText:
Ohhh joy... another one of these co-op gimmick games.

The game is near impossible to 100% complete alone, unless you buy it with a group of dedicated players... PASS, PASS, PASS!

Also, not only that, I wasn't really digging the way this game works... There's very little sense of progression and the perks you get for finding all the gems just aren't very rewarding. This game takes an insane amount of memorization and reflexs to conquer, especially alone... with a full group it divvy's up the work load a bit and is the proper way to play the game.

I'm also not a big fan of a progression system that doesn't actually reward the player. It doesn't exactly make any of the levels easier, just gives the player more useless attack animations to gawk at while they're running around telling an orb which wall to pass through, so it can hit some arbitrary switch, so you can finish the level... dumb.

reviewText:
I was super-excited when this game came out because I'm always looking for great co-op games to play with one of my friends. We played this for a few hours but eventually abandoned it when we got to a level we couldn't get past.

The game does a good job of forcing players to actually cooperate. But we found that when we only had 2-players that the levels became brutally hard. A single death meant all of the enemies homed in on the last man standing. Add in a few levels with insta-death from lazer-like barriers and we reached a level (after only 2 hours; the Slarth boss-fight) where the difficulty ramped up past our skill.

A quick check of Steam stats shows that only 19% of players beat Slarth.

It stopped being fun, so we moved on to other games. Maybe it is better with 4 players? Or maybe we're just not good enough (but I've played a decent amount of Super Meat Boy so I'm not TERRIBLE). Either way, the frustration exceeded the fun for us.

reviewText:
I don't even know why I bought this game, maybe it was shiny, who knows.

What I do know is this game is unfinished.
I honestly thought this was just an early access title like many of the others, but no it's not. I checked the store page 3 times to make sure.

This game has terrible audio mixing that makes most combat and music either too soft or not audible at all. The sounds are extremely far away if you are using headphones. Voice acting was bad, kinda the reason I wrote that first review after playing the starting trials. This game is just one gauntlet of completionist challenges. Honestly this is battle block theater if you take the platforming away and made it too serious.

Really the most laughable part is that they included a built-in twitch streaming platform. In a game that is so boring and requires co-op to be any fun, why do they need to include this? The game is the same ball puzzle, as far as I've played. Use your floating ball to activate shrines and destroy arbitrary spawners and statues.

You play the same character as everyone else just in different armor. I say charater but your just a gladiator without a name or face that wears different armor depending on what the lobby leader ♥♥♥♥♥es at you to be. It's a nice feature that you can change classes at whim so there's no commitment to a certain role. With the human husk of a character the story is terrible and the meat of the game is left to repetitive arenas one after the other.

Meh, the game's just boring, noticibly unpolished, and requires multiplayer for fun. Also multiplayer is buggy and won't connect at times.

So what can you do, play a better game at least.

reviewText:
FORCED: A game to improve your relationship with your significant other.

Ever get that feeling that your communication is lacking with your significant other?  You just wish there was a better way to work out *how* to talk to each other, and really be heard.  Well, here is the answer!  FORCED!  There is nothing to improve a relationship like coordinating where to pass a flaming ball of doom, who should focus fire on the boss and who should be on adds, or call out for your partner's help when you are getting overrun and have them valiantly come to your rescue.  This game *forces* you to work with your partner, to be aware of them at all times, and to understand that the survival of all parties involved is not only important, but practically integral to the success of many levels.

You will die.  You will die again, and again, and again.  There will be chronic confusion of who Balfus should be following.  There might be an unsavory word uttered under someone's breath here and there.  There might even be a declaration of, This isn't worth it

reviewText:
I was really expecting something good out of this title, with all the positive steam reviews and the promise of a fun puzzle-y RPG-y Co-op experience. What I got was a poorly optimized game with iOS game-style level design and netcode issues.

One of the primary mechanics in the game is this orb which each player can call to their location. It seems all puzzles, if you can even call them that, are based on this mechanic. The problem here is that these puzzles are all really uninventive and quite frankly boring, and using the orb for all puzzles doesn't make for a rewarding and interesting experience.

The level design reminds me of iOS games because of its infatuation of having really short, play-while-you're-on-the-toilet missions which give you a ranking between 1 and 3 depending on how well you did. One for completing the level, one for doing some special thing, and one for doing it quickly. I really think this is a horrible practice for PC games and I was hoping for some Diablo-style adventuring which would fit the game a lot better than how it is now.

These problems combined with the shoddy netcode (this was playing with 3 others with pings varying between 10-30ms) lead to a really unresponsive and disapointingly mediocre experience.

reviewText:
Not gonna lie, the single player isn't all that great, but it really isn't made to be a single player game.

Hook your rig up to a TV, get some controlers set up, and invite a few friends over and you'll be in for an absolute blast with this game. It's been half a decade since I've had this much fun playing a game with a group of friends. There are many games that have you playing in the same virtual space but not really playing it together. This game's ingenious design facilitates working together with the core mechanics without feeling like gimmicks.

Call your friends over, you must play this game.

reviewText:
Forced is like some insane mashup of an action RPG and basketball. The central mechanic of using a spirit-ball that much be passed around between players and used to activate, destroy or otherwise do anything important is an excellent co-op mechanic that's a ton of fun.

On the flip side, however, network play can be quite buggy, our party had several challenges fail to reset properly, issues connecting to hosts, and even a couple instances of two players being assigned to control of the same avatar.

These issues will hopefully be solved in future patches and the good news is that once you get the game running with everyone connected, it generally works quite well.

If you don't mind dealing with a few network bugs and have some friends to play with, Forced is an interesting and challenging co-op experience that isn't like anything else you're likely to have played.

reviewText:
Unless you like the party game dungeon crawl genre, I'd suggest skipping this, or waiting until it's fully finished. The glitches in the current version make it nearly unplayable.

Me and three friends tried playing a few games together - all of us had issues at different intervals using/equipping new skills, which then doesn't allow movement onto the next stage. Start over a new game.

Second try we experienced the same issue with different players. Third try I became de-synched during a match so the best I could do was attempt to keep up while my character slowly glitched around, lagging behind the party who were still fully functioning. I'd have to say this caused more unintended hilarity and fun in the game than when the game was running smoothly.

Toss in a few random crashes, and we haven't really bothered playing this since.

With a bit of polish it might be fun, and the graphics are ok" but not awe inspiring or even surprising. The level design is fairly straight forward

reviewText:
Unless you like the party game dungeon crawl genre, I'd suggest skipping this, or waiting until it's fully finished. The glitches in the current version make it nearly unplayable.

Me and three friends tried playing a few games together - all of us had issues at different intervals using/equipping new skills, which then doesn't allow movement onto the next stage. Start over a new game.

Second try we experienced the same issue with different players. Third try I became de-synched during a match so the best I could do was attempt to keep up while my character slowly glitched around, lagging behind the party who were still fully functioning. I'd have to say this caused more unintended hilarity and fun in the game than when the game was running smoothly.

Toss in a few random crashes, and we haven't really bothered playing this since.

With a bit of polish it might be fun, and the graphics are ok" but not awe inspiring or even surprising. The level design is fairly straight forward

reviewText:
Ok, here is a review which shouldn't be written by me as I don't have the play time to make a fair judgement, but it seems no-one else has discussed this.

5 words? FORCED. Seems good, no weight.

Okay, now for the lengthy bit....

What do you mean by 'no weight'? well, that's pretty straight forward really, every strike, stab, stomp and shot you perform has no impression of impact in the sound or visual effects, it doesn't feel like you are striking down someone to the pits of the earth, it feels like you are pushing them over so they gentle fall onto a bed.

Now, while this may make sense for the assassin-type character, this should not be the case with the warrior wielding a freaking HUGE FLAMING AXE.

Don't get me wrong, the art-style is nice, the puzzles are cool, the soundtrack would be nice if you didn't have to choose between silence or being deafened and perhaps that's also the reason the fighting sucks, you have to turn the game sounds so far down in order to be able to hear your friends that you miss out on any subtle sounds such as impacts and also miss out on the soundtrack. The guide however? Oh, he'll violate your ear-drums silly if you don't shut him up quickly.

Overall, FORCED probably isn't that bad, but it just wasn't mine or my friends' cup of tea. It was just boring, and trust me, I really wanted to enjoy it.

reviewText: This game is a puzzle co-operative game, you can play it single player or coop. The graphics are good, the performance is good, there isn't any stuttering, there aren't freezes. There aren't an excessive amount of controls to get used to, this game compared to other coop games like magicka has better coop synergy, partially because of its puzzle based nature. You can move and fire your bow which is a positive aspect about this game, I appreciated this because i've played Alien Swarm and i like the movement controls. There's an ability to switch between controller and keyboard and mouse and the support for controller is great. The negative aspects of this game is that people can't join while your playing, if they do then you have to restart your game if you want them to play, you can't make private matches, if someone leaves the game then you are taken back to multiplayer screen. I don't find any technical problems with this game.

reviewText:
As a someone who codes for a living and earned a degree in game design there are a few expectations I have. The biggest is a working program. I can overlook bugs, I can overlook the occassional crash. What I cannot do is spend hours trying to get something to work. This game seemed right up my alley considering I have very little time to game; relatively quick levels, freedom to revisit levels, and fairly simple controls (good for when I go weeks without being able to game.)
The problem I'm encountering is constant crashing, every time I played the game it crashed during a fight. Out of the 100+ games I have on Steam this and Dungeon Defenders don't work. Dungeon Defenders is an issue with my setup and I haven't had time to try the recommended fixes. Unfortunately this game doesn't even give me any clue as to why it crashes. It just freezes and can't be stopped through task manager because it stays as the fore window.
Although this cost next to nothing (on sale) I would still like something that doesn't require me to jump through a ton of hoops in order to get back to a working system.
Good effort and probably a great game, but I will never know because my time is more valuable than the reward of playing a game that has nothing truly unique.

reviewText: This game would be fun if it didn't have the mechanic of guiding a glowing ball around, while you're trying to fight off enemies. To me, it falls into the same category as Magicka, wherein it combines too much stuff into one game for it to be fun. But maybe I'm just getting crotchety and old and prefer my Gauntlet-esque games to be more like Gauntlet.

reviewText: This hack n' slash game will keep you on your toes, as it contains skill-based combat and puzzles that require you think on your feet.  It doesn't bother with the story and instead opts to focus entirely on the gameplay, which is fortunate because it is well thought-out.  Something of special note is that it is designed with co-op in mind, but while some games don't do any balancing, this game does ALL the balancing.  You have completely unique puzzles for anywhere from 1 to 4 players, and frequently puzzles will require all members of a team.\n\nIt has challenges for each stage (beat it in X time, etc), but they are absurdly difficult, so I recommend you play through the story, then that's it.  Get it on a sale.

reviewText:
I was worried that this game would be too much like Diablo3/Torchlight .

However Forced has many uniqe mechanics which separate it from the old formula. Your character is followed by the light ball called Balfus who will interact with various objects in game . This escpecially very fun in coop mod where players have to share the ball .

This game also reminds me crash bandicoot because each level features 3 crystals which you can unlock by completing challanges . Crystal basicly unlock new skills which you can use between 4 uniqe characters .

It is not really RPG game but more like survivor arena . Also I should note that this game utilizes steam community very well . It keeps scores of all players,friends and uses profile icons . Pretty cool

If you can get it under $15 I highly recommend it .

8/10

reviewText: If I'm to classify Forced as anything, it's a cooperative MOPA - Multiplayer Online Puzzler Arena ;)\n\nReally good co-op game, with both fun and challenging combat system and clever but not too convoluted action-oriented puzzles, both rewarding you greatly for good teamwork and communication. Since each mission is its own little arena it's easy to pick up and play for a little while with people joining and leaving as they like, although I'd encourage you to play with friends to get the most (screaming and fighting over the shiny ball) out of it! ^^ Each class is tied to weapons and you level" all the classes at the same time. Classes are divided between players so you can't play the same thing
date: which also encourages teamwork and letting the best suited for different tasks do their thing
recommended: but you can also switch classes freely between each mission. Since you can also skip some missions
hoursPlayed: it means you can decide difficulty by avoiding harder ones if you really want to
voteText: but I for one found the difficulty on an appropriate level. As far as co-op games goes this one is nearly perfect.\n\nThe controls feels sharp and responsive
helpfulPercent: and the skills fairly intuitive. You can fight a boss without taking damage by timing dodges perfectly
votesHelpful: or you can die miserably by doing it poorly. There's a nice balance between individual skill and teamwork that you usually (hopefully) find in MOBAs like LoL and DotA
votesTotal: but to me what it reminds me most of is running dungeons in WoW
votesFunny: minus the gear frenzy and hunter pets pulling all the mobs. Overall
commentsCount: I strongly recommend Forced
column16: especially in four-packs.\n\nTrying to think of anything bad... we've had occasional random lag/framedrops for no apparent reason
column17: but not a lot. There used to be some crippling network issues that appear to have been resolved. It seems some of the missions are in fact impossible to solo
column18: but since you can skip some levels that may be possible to go around

reviewText:
I picked up this game in a 4-pack in the hopes that I could play through it with my friends, and while that didn't happen, it was still an excellent experience.  The gameplay is beautiful in its simplicity, and hair-pullingly hard as a solo experience, though I suppose I can't say that any of my failures were anyone's fault by mine.

It may seem silly, but I believe that this game truly shines in its progression, which gave way to effective level design. There are no discrete levels, only up to three gems earned in each stage as a reward for completion, completing a special challenge during the level, and completing the level within a certain time limit.  New skills are unlocked after players amass enough gems.  As I earned gem after gem, it rewarded me with new toys to play with because of it.  Because there is no leveling up, there is no stat inflation, and each level is designed to challenge players based solely on the mechanics it presents, and I think that goes a long way toward the game's effective balance of challenge and reward.

Each of the four classes plays differently, which makes replaying levels to earn more gems, or improve a time, or even just for the hell of it that much more entertaining.  With all of those possible combinations, how could one resist experimentation?  It was that process of refining my approach to a level until I had conquered it that truly made the experience memorable for me, and I'd highly recommend it for anyone who's up for that sort of challenge.

reviewText:
I really hate having to recommend against getting this game. I really wanted to like it but the experience the game gave just declined over the course of 14 hours. Let's start from the beginning.

I bought this game pretty much right after it came out in 2013 and played it with 2 other friends. The net-code was unstable at launch which made it extremely difficult to get online co-op games (one of the main selling points) to work. When it did work though it was great entertainment. However, an unstable multiplayer was not the only mechanical issue I ran into and I crashed several times. Add numerous bugs and you have a less than stellar experience. A year later I picked up the game to finish it and while the net-code has gotten better it's still wonky and there are still bugs throughout, in fact the last boss fight of the game was more or less ruined as the big bad evil guy crapped out on me and was stuck in his walking cycle unnable to attack.

Even with those mechanical flaws I still managed to have a good time but at the halfway mark of the game things just go down hill. See the game is structured a lot like an old Crash Bandicoot game (the second one to be exact). The game is split into worlds that has a series of levels along with a boss fight. Every level has 3 crystals to obtain. The first is obtained by simply beating the level, the second by completing a challenge tied to the level and finally a crystal based on completion time.

The structure works really well and here's why: The game is a mix of RPG, Hack 'N' Slash and light Puzzle elements. Your character has active abilities, passive abilities and a special ability tied to each of the 4 classes (Hammer charges over time, bow can be charged manually, shield blocks etc.). However, in order gain new abilities you need to get crystals by beating levels. This creates a very real incentive to complete levels several times to pick up all the crystals.

This brings us to the levels themselves and the puzzle element. Throughout the game you'll be escorted by Balfus a flying orb that might as well have been called Navi. Balfus has a lot of quips throughout the game and he happily chats away whenever he's given the chance and becomes real grating, real fast. Especially when constantly replaying levels to get those final crystals. Now the levels are structured so that you need Balfus to activate several items and objects by making him fly into them and for the first half of the game it's great fun to play with all the different objects in the world and there are some really creative puzzles in there. Like I said though, at the half way point it seriously starts to feel like you're simply going through the motions and things become repetitive just like Balfus' endlessly repeating lines.

Another few gripes I feel deserve mentioning are the bosses whom have way to much health for their own good, seriously they are ♥♥♥♥ing sponges soaking damage like high-end kleenexes. The mark system which adds extra damage from abilities and basic attacks don't do enough to quickly wear down bosses at a reasonable rate and the boss levels which are supposed to be epic become tedious. The fact that the invisible creatures can only be spotted by Balfus and the fact there's only one Balfus and most likely more than one player it is aggrivating to kill just one, especially when they have enough health to soak several fully marked abilities. I could go on but I think I've made my point.

In conclusion, I feel really bad for not recommending the game because I know this is the first game by the dev team and I know they worked really hard on it, but it just lacks polish and the player-experience is not optimal as a result. If you really want to play this game, get it on sale.

reviewText:
If you want a good coop game then look elsewhere!

Where to start? Want deep character customization? Too bad! Pick between four set characters (if a buddy grabs your favorite character, you have to play as a different one) with only one weapon set per character. while you can certainly upgrade their abilities and switch between a few special powers per character, its hardly in depth enough to make you feel like you have the ability to make important changes to your character to augment to your own playing style. And with zero loot in the game you aren't allowed to even optimize your character's gear in any way.

Howabout the maps? Well, don't play this game expecting long sprawling dungeons, each level is more of a small arena with waves of enemies and little puzzles to solve. And when I mean arena I literally mean a smallish circular map where enemies will run in from doorways on the outside as well as from a few spawners. Its been extremely difficult to connect with friends, but when working the teamwork required to get through these levels is simple, but enjoyable enough (though it is a simple button masher) when played in coop, however that leads me to the greatest problem of this game in my opinion:

When playing coop with friends with each of you on DIFFERENT computers, you are still forced to share the camera as if playing a couch coop with your buddies on the same screen. This can lead to anything from mild annoyance to intense frustration while playing. I can think of nothing more frustrating while trying to play this game then when my character is pushed off the screen because my friends are on the other side of the screen, and I am now forced to fight blindly or ask my friends to stop what they're doing and come back to my side of the arena. This problem might not be as frustrating when played with just 1-2 other friends, but if you get a full group of four together you'll run into this problem often. Its possible this has been fixed, though the fact that you were ever forced (no pun intended) to play this way in the first place is ridiculous!

In terms of replayability, there is no randomness to this game, or any abundance of places you might of missed to explore. The game's main sense of replayability comes in the fact that each arena playthrough is timed, and ranked among others. The incentive being to replay the arena to try and get a better score.

There's a reason why most of the people reviewing this game don't make it past twenty hours of game time... However, that being said, if this sounds like the type of game you want to play then by all means give it a whirl. Just don't be fooled into thinking that this game will be at all like an in depth rpg dungeon crawler. If you're looking for that type of game look elsewhere.

reviewText:
The camera for multiplayer in this game is horribly broken. When the players are further apart than half a screen, your view gets offset and zoomed out to keep all players onscreen. You are no longer the center of your screen. It was a very poor design choice.

Secondly, some of the challenges require specific skill combinations. Part of the challenge is figuring that out. I detest this use of the skill sets. I would like to play using skills I enjoy, not skills that I must use to progress. That is another very poor design choice.

My last gripe is that I don't feel like the game has much replayability. Once I complete a very difficult task and get the extra gem, I don't want to do it ever again. That isn't a desireable feature for any game.

reviewText: This game reminded me of Gauntlet, so my 3 friends and I got it one night and decided to attempt to record it for my YouTube. The sad truth is the game is such garbage that I had 3 corrupted video files before I stopped trying.\n\nBetween the 4 of us, my friends and I have between medium and advanced gaming rigs... mine being the best. All four of us had repeated game crashes every time we tabbed out of the game, for me it was to start/stop Audacity and for them it was either accident or to check their Twitch streams. However if that was the only issue it wouldn't be too bad, the major issue is this crash in the ended up causing all of our computers to crash and need to be manually restarted. After the 3rd try I stopped tabbing out and decided to run everything before opening the gamem which worked until one of my friends accidentally hit Main Menu". When he did this
date: it kicked the 3 remaining players out of the game
voteText: the least minor thing but during our play none of us could use the controller even though it was an option. The controller settingers were optimized however every time one of us selected the controller it wouldn't allow that person to "ready-up" until they went back to the keyboard. Why even make something an option if your game won't allow you to use it?\n\nThis game honestly isn't worth your time. reviewText:
FORCED is an interesting game, to say the least. I played it heavily during the initial development, before it was on Steam.

The game is a mixture of time trials and Diablo-esque co-op combat, this means you have a persistant character that you level up in either singleplayer, or co-operative levels. These levels involve combat, as well as puzzle solving mechanics where players move and place floating orbs over certain objects for a variety of effects.

If you enjoy time challanges, Diablo, or are looking for a co-op game with friends you will be hard pressed to find a better value than FORCED at the current time!

You can see my other opinions on the game here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NKAMfFPIn0A

reviewText:
A fun game for both playing solo and with friends.  While I've not had any issues with the game other than some graphical glitches, it's been nice to see the developers actively improving the game (better multiplayer connections, better controller support, other bug fixes, and several tweaks to solo play).

It's an action RPG in the same genre as Diablo, Torchlight, etc., but with several twists.  It's much more puzzle based, but combat is still an integral part.  Classes are based on the 4 available weapons, and switching classes can be done with no penalty between levels.  Skills are unlocked by completing levels and challenges (one time and one other per level) to get crystals, which unlock abilities at certain numbers and is not tied to a class.  There's no gear progression, so there's no grinding.  In multiplayer, everyone has to have a crystal for it to be available for that play session, so everyone is on an equal footing.

I picked this up because it was compatible with Macs, and I've really enjoyed it.  I've played with 1, 2, 3, and 4 players, tried all 4 classes and have 72/75 crystals.

Some levels/challenges are significantly easier for either solo or multiplayer (time challenges tend to be more relaxed in multiplayer, but other challenges that require no one screwing up is much easier solo).  Also, the archer seems to be much more powerful compared to the other classes in solo because it is the only class with a ranged basic attack.  Furthermore, once you have 75/75 crystals, I feel there's currently limited replay value, even if you choose a different class.  However, there's a promise for more endgame" content beyond the current survival mode."

reviewText:
This game, for the low price of $7.49 that I picked up during the winter sales has proven to be worth every cent. The challenges that my friends and I faced has caused us the necessary frustration but the possibility of completing it has kept us at it. We are 70% past the game and honestly, my only wish were that it could be longer as we do love the game.

The upside are the stages which are initially simple but you can opt to do the challenges which are much harder and have forced our team to use special set-ups in our attempt to conquer them. A fond way to think of it would be like a 10-25 man dungeon raid you would experience in some of the MMO's but that your team was reduced to 4, including you. Although you can play it single player, it is a much better game to play with friends and I would say your enjoyment rises exponentially with each friend you play with.

The downside is that the game is relatively short, if you play without the challenges, you can easily complete in maximum of 1-2 days?

This is one of the most challenging games and its still worth every cent.

reviewText:
(At the moment I wouldnt be recommending this game to people I know.)

Whilst the concept of this game is very good, combining the elements of an arena fighting game with puzzle mechanics. Myself and my friends have become gradually annoyed many times with little problems that arise from the strange lag, collision detection, clunky camera and online getting the game to linkup.

Problems that arose during play
- Sometimes found the Spirit orb wouldnt hit shrines or objects when it appeared that it passed directly into them.
- When players were spreadout the camera wouldnt help you out.
- We had some lag issues between players from UK and Sweden. (no problems in other games)
-The online lobby had a few hiccups when setting up the match. (not seeing when Ready)

Somethings id love to see added/fixed/updating
- rolling or sprint. (due to the fact that everytime I tried to move away from enemies they would keep up and hit me this may or may not have been due to lag (unsure)
- individual cameras for players with a button for map view to see other players.
- fixing cutscenes and specific little issues with the game.

If this is slightly better i would hate to see what the original was like"
Cheers Jezereth."

reviewText: I enjoyed the combat aspect of the game, the variations on possible builds, and the gem rewarding achievement system. reviewText: I have to congratulate this game for doing something no other piece of software ever managed to do. It manages to shut down both my monitors for 10 minutes of inactivity (at least that's my best guess, maybe it just lulls my graphics card to sleep after a little while), even though I was playing the game for those 10 minutes, which means moving the mouse around and using the keyboard. What's even more impressive is that the same happens whether I play in full screen or windowed mode. And the most impressive thing of all... this means that I can not tab out of the game leaving hard reset button on my case as the only possible way out.\n\nIn a way this is actually quite a beautiful accomplishment and I could just simply turn off that setting on my PC when I play this game and see if that would help. Or I could also just uninstall this and move on with my life... which I ultimately decided is a healthier option.

reviewText:
Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This game is a Twin stick Brawler.



Interface/Menu/Settings
There is a Volume bar slider. Master, Sound and music. (Master is both).
You can play this Co-op or single player.
You can choose between Campaign or Survival mode.
You are able to play this game with a Xbox controller. However without Rumble.
it has alot of Resolution Sizes.
You can play fullscreen or window mode.
You can turn on the subtitles.
The game has many different Languages.
You can Choose the Quality level.
You are able to turn on or off the Vsync
There is a ranking.
You are able to make multiple Profiles.

reviewText: I have to congratulate this game for doing something no other piece of software ever managed to do. It manages to shut down both my monitors for 10 minutes of inactivity (at least that's my best guess, maybe it just lulls my graphics card to sleep after a little while), even though I was playing the game for those 10 minutes, which means moving the mouse around and using the keyboard. What's even more impressive is that the same happens whether I play in full screen or windowed mode. And the most impressive thing of all... this means that I can not tab out of the game leaving hard reset button on my case as the only possible way out.\n\nIn a way this is actually quite a beautiful accomplishment and I could just simply turn off that setting on my PC when I play this game and see if that would help. Or I could also just uninstall this and move on with my life... which I ultimately decided is a healthier option.

reviewText:
Bought it on sale for $2. Its an alright puzzle game, but nothing particularly compelling. Definitely not worth the $14.99 sticker price.

Pros: Different weapon sets are useful for different levels, decent co-op play. Low cost on sale.
Bosses you beat become toned down normal enemies in following levels, which introduces some neat mechanics in mundane combat.

cons: Almost no replayability. Progression requires you to beat levels under a timer and while adhering to generally more difficult challenges, so look forward to playing all of them several times as you go through the story.
Low variety of enemies. You'll see the same ones every single level.
Puzzles are highly simplistic. Out of 20 story levels only a handful aren't painfully obvious. About half of challenges are super easy to get and you'll end up reaching them just by playing the level, the rest are frustrating and include a strong element of luck requiring you to replay the level multiple times.
Stunlock for days. Not all classes have invincibility frames, and several enemy types can pin you against the wall or dogpile you and stunlock you to death. The completely invisible enemies that attack from invis without breaking it only add to this, as they make some attacks legitimately unavoidable.
Camera is terribad. It has a maximum zoom and a fixed angle, combined with all the knockbacks its not unsual to have people stuck offscreen.
Almost no multiplayer scene: less than five games at a time, coming off of an 85% off sale. Unless you've got friends who own it or buy a fourpack look forward to going it alone.

reviewText:
This is a challenging game, more because if you don't have a team some things seem impossible.
The game works in a way where you level up by gathering crystals which you get from: Finishing a level, Finishing it within a certain amount of time, or doing a challenge in the level. Recently they have added so you can get up to 12 more crystals from Survival modes, but it's not as helpful late game as it is doing it as early as possible.
As you level up you gain Perks, Abilities, or a spot for a new one.
However, the later it gets the more crystals you will need to get new things, easily trapping you with whatever you have and hoping that you can beat the next level.
What I don't like is that even if you play the same level 50 times, you will not get anything from it, especially if you're stuck on it and you can't do any other time/challenge things.
I'm still not sure if I recommend this game, it's really frustaring when you stand there with no ways to get the next unlock, but you're also stuck and can't continue.

In the end, I will not recommend the game, for the way it treats unlocks, and singleplayer is nearly unable to do if you're an achivement ♥♥♥♥♥ like I am.

reviewText:
Forced is an arena challenge/puzzle game with co-op than can suck out your time like nothing else.
In this game you're a tribesmen trying to earn your freedom , being helped by the spirit master, sorting through several challenges (total of 25 levels including final boss) to earn power.
Each time you complete a level you earn a crystal, if you complete it again doing the time challenge or the skill challenge, some are really hard even playing with 3 friends, what's unfair is than some of the skills and passives require a lot of crystals, being the final passive of each class requiring 75, by then you would have completed the game 100% so why would you keep playing?.
The 4 classes are spirit blades some sort of assasin, Volcanic hammer the warrior,  The Frost Shield being the paladin and the Storm bow being the archer (obviously), you can swap classes anytime before tackling on a level without any kind of penalty.
The levels are either purify temples, destroy stuff, kill stuff, and kill moar stuff, all of them requires strategical use of the spirit mentor which can heal you or aid you depending which shrines you use him to activate, some are really fun like the arena with the spinning laser in the centre, and challenge don't take cover from it.
The game is great fun with friends but frustrating very frustrating if you wish to proceed all the way to winning the game, you can grab it during sales fairly cheap to try with friends

reviewText:
I would defenitly recommend this game. It's one, if not, THE funnest (local) co-op game I have played with friends. I say local, because I mainly played this mode, only a few times online/single player. And local is probably where the most fun is, since communication is a BIG part of the game.

I think I like about anything in the game, it's challenging, has a satisfying progression system, the challenges give levels nice variations, very descent amount of content, the orb makes for some unique gameplay, option to choose out of a good amount of character skills (and easy to change it up)

I think everyone who loves to play co-op with friends should have this game in their library. If there ever is a sequel, I will buy it in a heartbeat. It's a shame there aren't more games like this one. A true gem in my opinion.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Forced is a beautiful game and clearly a labour of love on the part of its creators. I picked it up to play with one other friend, but I'm excited to try 3- and 4-player mode sometime in the future. It's hectic fun, challenging without being too grindy or rage-inducing. It's a charming, colourful top-down ARPG hack-and-slash with puzzle elements, with a silent protagonist (or four) backed up by a surprisingly witty supporting cast, vibrant level design and a solid and uncomplicated - yet functional - combat and progression system. Thoroughly recommend, though I hear the single-player mode is nothing to write home about. The true pleasure of this game, though, lies in the co-op mode. Grab a friend or three and dive right in.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Very fun local co-op both times I've played, a day with one friend, and a few days with two of my siblings. Challenges are a nice feature, which allow you to unlock more skills and have a bunch of fun in doing so. Skills are varied, and the classes all play differently - if you're playing with mulitple players, it's fun to have a quick discussion about how your team's skills interrelate and so switch them up appropriately for a given challenge.
Challenges exist both as time challenges and level-specific challenges, some as basic as killing a certain enemy in a specifc way, whilst others are very niche, such as to solving a puzzle and touching a flag,
I haven't finished this game, but as soon as I've got the local players ready we'll be jumping straight onto this game to get those last few skills and levels complete.
If it's on sale, this is a very cheap way to have several hours of fun with your friends. I can't vouch for online co-op being fantastic, however if you and your friends have good microphones and internet connections I don't see why it should be much worse than playing with them in the flesh.
We all used console controllers (Official Xbox 360 controller with dongle, Xbox One controller with USB cable, and PS3 controllers with Better DS3 - only the PS3 controllers broke down on occasion), and the controls themselves are perfectly simple and easy to pick up.

tl;dr: Cheap game, lots of fun. Definitely worth your money. Grab some friends (and their controllers) and progress as much as you can!

reviewText: Clever and challenging action rpg but best played with 4 friends. Bought the 4 pack during the last steam sale and had a blast going through the levels. Each level is a cleverly designed arena with unique challenges. While difficult to beat the first time, each level also has a time trial and a bonus objective to complete. Beating levels, clearing under a time limit, and completing the bonus objective provides gems which unlock upgrades. Upgrades are unlocked at gem levels, so you can switch between any of the 4 playable characters at any time. Almost all the upgrades are useful and unique, so different players can have very different styles even with the same character.\n\nMy only complaint about the game is that one of the later levels appears to be bugged in multiplayer and can't be completed.

reviewText: Four-player couch co-op drew us in, but the tactical team-based-puzzles required us to recognize our selfish inclinations, apologize, and learn to rely on one another. reviewText:
I totally recommend this game, even though (and perhaps just exactly why) some levels are CRAZY hard (even annoying a times). The central element of the game lies in swapping between the different characters and maybe even changing the number of people playing (I finished all trials with in 2player, except for the second-to-last one, which I did alone).
Graphics and music are standard in quality, nothing extraordinary, the story even a little sub-standard, but that's not quite the point with games like this one.
The only annoying technical aspect is the network performance, which, even though it was improved with just about every update, still isn't perfect now.
All in all, I award this game 4.5 stars, the half one being lost because of the lagging issues, the weak story and because some trials are just too hard.

reviewText: Man, I've played a ton of puzzle games in my days, but this one takes the cake. So get this. You get to choose 1 of 4 classes, all with unique abilities and such, and up to 4 people can play together. Every level has some kind of catch to it. Some are timed, some have puzzles you have to solve, and some spawn enemies constantly unless youcan find out how to stop them. After every 5-6 levels, there's a boss. The bosses are freakin cool as hell. And the combat is awesome. Those abilities I talked about? You unlock more by doing better in the puzzles. The only downside I can think of is that you are constantly followed by WIsp from DotA 2. And he talks. Wisp doesnt talk, he makes bleepbloop sounds. Stupid Wisp, learn your place.

reviewText:
Realy good coop game!
Kind of Diablo-like without loot or exp. You collect runes by completing level, their challenge and the time limit on them. Mor runes = more available skills; easy as that.
Not to easy, you got to be fast, there are nice bosses and mini-bosses and there are puzzles to solve.
Even alone i would say this is viable.

The big problem at hand is the poor netcodeing. You need to readjust router-ports, anti-vir and firewalls and it will still not tell you your NAT is ok. Aside from beeing unable to connect to ppl this will also cause heavy lags in mp (which are a bad thing if you do time trails or challenges ...), but well not with everybody ...

Seeing that the connecting probs cause the mp to be friend-only-groups or half-way-dead i would say: Do not buy above 10€.

reviewText:
Forced is one of those games to make you rage uncontrollably. Its difficult, sometimes obtuse, and requires impeccable communication. And its damn fun. This isn't a game you can autopilot through. You have to be on your A game 100% of the time, which for me meant taking a break every couple of levels. However the completion of a challenge is extremely rewarding.

Unlike many hack and slashers, this game does not focus on equipment or leveling skills, instead it provides skills that have distinct tradeoffs against other skills and may need to be optimized between levels. Your characters never get more health or do more damage, but they do get skills that combo together to do more damage.

Art style was basic but competent, character readability was very good. Sound was basic but competent.

I got this game as early access and was impressed by the improvement and overall progress that the devs accomplished. The game has online coop and local coop with up to 4 players. While you can play by yourself, its singnificantly more fun with friends.

reviewText:
Do you hate using the mouse to both move and attack?

Well FORCED is for you.
The first thing you should know is that this isn't a straight up Diablo clone. The game takes place in many small trials that could take minutes to complete. Each trial contains puzzles and enemy encounters. Although usually boss rooms don't contain many puzzles.

The pick up and play gameplay is definitely something that keeps me coming back for more. Also there are four classes with different skills, but they all level at the same time and you can jump between them. Which is nice, although I'm not quite sure how balanced this is.

reviewText: Great Game overall.  Forced is a very intense game that requires a lot of conentration and a lot of awareness. Its a fun and entertaining game to play with friends, but I don't recommend this for beginners.
